title: Microsoft working on software that could help prevent crashes...
text:
Microsoft and the City of Bellevue are teaming up to prevent bicyclists and pedestrians from being hit by cars.
The project would use the city's traffic cameras.
There are 200 cameras that the city would use, with help from Microsoft, to predict when and where pedestrians and bicyclists are most at risk of being hit by a car.
If the technology were used at an intersection, it would tell the city what time of day and which direction a bicyclist was going when they were hit or nearly hit by a car.
Traffic cameras in Bellevue already document drivers running red lights at certain intersections.
But for the new project, computer engineers at Microsoft are working on software that would analyze traffic camera video, and could see when bicyclists are in danger.
The program will, in theory, determine how fast a car or bike is going and predict their trajectory.
According to the tech blog GeekWire, the software uses algorithms to identify potential collisions.
The results could lead to changes to crosswalks or traffic signals, different timing of red lights, or even show which streets could use a dedicated bike lane.
Microsoft is already working on a prototype using footage from cameras on its campus.
Developers think it could be the key for cities to make streets safer.
They hope to have a working system up and running in the next year.
